channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Dozens killed in Odessa clashes
item.description: At least 31 people have been killed in a fire in an official building amid clashes between pro-Russian activists and government supporters in Odessa, in south-west Ukraine.

item.title: Afghan landslide 'kills hundreds'
item.description: At least 350 people have been killed and many more are missing, the UN says, after a landslide hit the Afghan province of Badakhshan.

item.title: Samsung ordered to pay Apple $119.6m
item.description: Samsung is ordered to pay $119.6m (Â£71m) to Apple by a US court for infringing two of its patents, in the latest lawsuit involving the two tech giants.

item.title: US confirms first case of Mers virus
item.description: Health officials report the first case of Mers coronavirus in the US after a man fell ill following travel to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Museum to take 'exploding' whales
item.description: Canada's Royal Ontario Museum will take two blue whale carcasses that washed up on the coast of western Newfoundland.

item.title: Obama calls for death penalty review
item.description: US President Barack Obama will ask Attorney General Eric Holder to review the death penalty following a botched execution.

item.title: US and Germany 'at odds' over spying
item.description: The US and Germany remain at odds over digital spying and privacy policy, US President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel say.

item.title: Gay gets one-year ban for doping
item.description: American former 100m and 200m world champion Tyson Gay is banned for a year after testing positive for a banned substance.

item.title: US House to open new Benghazi inquiry
item.description: The House speaker says he will convene a committee to investigate the White House response to the attack on the US consulate in Libya in 2012.

item.title: Alaska 'reality show' troopers shot
item.description: A teenager is arrested in connection with the fatal shooting in Alaska of two state troopers who appeared in a reality television show.

item.title: Nigeria appeal for girls' photos
item.description: Police in Nigeria appeal to parents of more than 200 abducted schoolgirls to come forward with their photographs to confirm the number of missing.

item.title: Ecclestone 'blackmail' challenged
item.description: German prosecutors contest claims by F1 boss Bernie Ecclestone that he was blackmailed into paying $45m to a German banker.

item.title: Max Clifford jailed for eight years
item.description: UK publicist Max Clifford is jailed for total of eight years for eight indecent assaults against young women.

item.title: Syrian rebels 'to pull out of Homs'
item.description: Opposition fighters are to be allowed to withdraw from besieged parts of the Syrian city of Homs under a deal with the government, reports say.

item.title: Police inquiry over Peaches' death
item.description: Police launch a criminal inquiry after it emerges that heroin was likely to have played a part in the death of Peaches Geldof.

item.title: Dutch release Pim Fortuyn's killer
item.description: The Dutch authorities release the man who murdered the flamboyant anti-immigration politician Pim Fortuyn in 2002, now that he has served 11 years in jail.

item.title: VIDEO: New subprime lending boom in the US
item.description: Subprime lending is booming once again in the US - not for home loans, but for cars.

item.title: VIDEO: Desolate ghost towns of S Sudan
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry is visiting South Sudan and has warned that more peacekeepers must be rapidly deployed to end the conflict.

item.title: VIDEO: Boko Haram 'now major threat'
item.description: The Islamist militant group Boko Haram said it was behind a huge bombing last month

item.title: VIDEO: Views from Moscow on Ukraine crisis
item.description: Rafael Saakov from the BBC's Russian Service went out into the streets of Moscow to get people's opinions about what is happening in east Ukraine.

item.title: VIDEO: One-minute World News
item.description: Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.

item.title: VIDEO: What do astronauts eat in space?
item.description: The UK Space Agency is launching a competition for schoolchildren to design a meal for British astronaut Tim Peake.

item.title: VIDEO: NYC in the footsteps of Dylan Thomas
item.description: The centenary of Dylan Thomas's birth is being celebrated this year. Tomos Morgan has taken a walk in Thomas's footsteps around the city of New York, where the Welsh poet died.

item.title: VIDEO: Fertility on a shoestring
item.description: The stigma of childlessness in South Africa can be devastating, but fertility treatment is prohibitively expensive for most couples. Now one Cape Town clinic is doing everything it can to make it more affordable.

item.title: Stephen Hawking: Beware smart machines
item.description: What in the World: Scientists warn of uncontrollable machine intelligence, Egyptian aid creates a new generation of militants, and a "Chinese Century" delayed.

item.title: O'Sullivan wins to reach world final
item.description: Defending champion Ronnie O'Sullivan beats Barry Hawkins 17-7 to reach the World Championship final.

item.title: Fellaini saddened by Moyes sacking
item.description: Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini was "sad" to see David Moyes sacked as manager last month.

item.title: Guardiola 'will not change philosophy'
item.description: Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola will not change his 'tiki-taka' style, despite the club's Champions League exit.

item.title: Everton v Manchester City
item.description: Everton captain Phil Jagielka returns to the squad after a 10-week absence as title hopefuls Man City visit Goodison Park.

item.title: D-day for Football League clubs
item.description: Saturday marks the final day of the Football League season, with promotion and relegation issues to be decided.

item.title: Praised for pointing a gun
item.description: Thousands of Israelis have "liked" a Facebook page supporting a soldier who cocked his gun at a young Palestinian.

item.title: When May Day meets social media
item.description: "May Day" is trending around the world, but nowhere more so than Turkey where they have been violent clashes.

item.title: US sees strong jobs growth in April
item.description: The US economy adds 288,000 jobs in April, a much stronger number than economists were expecting, and the unemployment rate falls to 6.3%.

item.title: News Corp buys 'bodice ripper' house
item.description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation pays $415m for Harlequin, a Canadian publisher of 'bodice ripper' romance fiction.

item.title: Twitter tries out 'mute' feature
item.description: Twitter is trialling a feature in its mobile apps that allows users to mute accounts that are becoming irritating.

item.title: Windows XP users to get Explorer fix
item.description: Microsoft says users of its Windows XP operating system will also get the security update it has issued to fix a flaw in the Internet Explorer browser.

item.title: BBC taking Clarkson clip 'seriously'
item.description: The BBC says it has left Jeremy Clarkson "in no doubt about how seriously" it is treating allegations that he used racist language while filming Top Gear.

item.title: Matt Smith set for Terminator reboot
item.description: Paramount Pictures announce Matt Smith is to star opposite Arnold Schwarzenegger in the reboot of the terminator franchise.

item.title: Concerns grow over deadly pig virus
item.description: France is expected to suspend some pig-related imports as worries grow over the spread of a deadly swine virus.

item.title: Astronaut launches space meal contest
item.description: British Astronaut Tim Peake has asked schoolchildren to create a meal for him to eat in space.

item.title: Baby heart risk for pregnant smokers
item.description: Babies born to women over 35 who smoke are at greater risk of having specific heart defects, suggests American research.

item.title: Under-fives death rate 'high in UK'
item.description: The UK has one of the highest rates of death for children under five in Western Europe, according to new research published in The Lancet.

item.title: F1 'spy-gate' mechanic Stepney dies
Froome second in Tour de Romandie
item.description: Defending champion Chris Froome finishes second after a sprint finish in stage three of the Tour de Romandie in Switzerland.

item.title: How the US Communist Party survived
item.description: Like fellow movements around the world, the US Communist Party suffered a crippling blow with the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. But a small group of die-hard members persevered.

item.title: The man with 42 hours to get home
item.description: When Peter Hodes travels abroad he always makes sure to get home within 42 hours. The reason? He's a volunteer courier carrying life-saving stem cells.

item.title: Tea party not dead yet in Texas
item.description: National losses for tea party Republicans Texas last year were considered a high-water mark for the movement, but the BBC's Mark Mardell says that does not mean tea party is done in US politics.

item.title: Why Kentucky might 'Ditch Mitch'
item.description: The BBC's Mark Mardell reports from Kentucky, where conservatives are campaigning to remove one of the US' longest serving Republicans from office.

item.title: Honduras children 'killed by gangs'
item.description: Authorities in Honduras are investigating the deaths of at least seven children who may have been murdered after refusing to join criminal gangs.

item.title: Uruguay unveils legal marijuana plan
item.description: Uruguay's authorities reveal how marijuana will be produced and sold legally in the country at less than $1 a gramme.

item.title: US pushes South Sudan rivals to talk
item.description: South Sudan's president has agreed to hold direct talks to end the conflict in the country with his rival, US Secretary of State John Kerry says.

item.title: Students killed in Ethiopia protest
item.description: At least nine students have died during days of protests in Ethiopia's Oromia state, the government says - a witness tells the BBC 47 were killed.

item.title: Plane search 'could take a year'
item.description: The official leading the hunt for the missing Malaysian airliner MH370 says a full search of the suspected crash area could take up to a year.

item.title: Arrests over Philippine 'sextortion'
item.description: Police in the Philippines say they have arrested dozens of suspects linked to an online cybersex blackmail syndicate.

item.title: Fire causes explosion of rotten fish
item.description: A fire in a warehouse on the east coast of Sweden causes cans of fermented herring to explode and go flying through the air.

item.title: Police given more time to quiz Adams
item.description: Police in Northern Ireland are given more time to question Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams in connection with the 1972 murder of Jean McConville.

item.title: Gunmen storm Libyan security HQ
item.description: Gunmen in the Libyan city of Benghazi have raided a security headquarters, sparking clashes in which at least nine people died, officials say.

item.title: Tunisia MPs approve electoral law
item.description: Tunisia's interim parliament takes one of the last steps towards the country becoming a full democracy by approving a new electoral law.

item.title: NBA owners vote for Clippers sale
item.description: A group representing NBA team owners agrees to proceed with efforts to force the sale of the LA Clippers following a heated race row.

item.title: Toronto Mayor Rob Ford enters rehab
item.description: Rob Ford is starting a 30-day treatment course, as police investigate a new video that allegedly shows the mayor smoking crack cocaine.

item.title: Children 'see harmful television'
item.description: Children are being exposed to harmful television material before the 9pm watershed, according to head teachers.

item.title: Teens arrested in school murder plot
item.description: Two schoolgirls are arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to commit murder following an incident at a school in Caerphilly county.

item.title: Heathrow flight 'Mers' virus warning
item.description: UK health officials issue advice to passengers after a suspected case of the Mers respiratory virus on board a flight from Saudi Arabia to London.

item.title: Care staff charged with manslaughter
item.description: Two care workers appear in court charged with manslaughter after the death of a 91-year-old woman.

item.title: Week in pictures: 26 April - 2 May 2014
item.description: News photos from the past week

item.title: Day in pictures: 2 May 2014
item.description: News photos from past 24 hours: 2 May

item.title: Latin America & Caribbean - Part 2
item.description: Queen's Baton Relay reaches Latin America and the Caribbean

item.title: In pictures: US flooding and storms
item.description: Major storm systems hit the eastern half of the US

item.title: Your pictures: Pinhole
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of "pinhole"

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards 2014
item.description: The winners of the Sony World Photography Awards

item.title: Day in pictures: 1 May 2014
item.description: News photos from past 24 hours: 1 May

item.title: In pictures: Desperate plight of Muslims in Myanmar camp
item.description: Myanmar's displaced Muslims fight to survive

item.title: How Bob Hoskins helped adults learn to read
item.description: How Bob Hoskins helped adults learn to read

item.title: A tale of two US gun ranges
item.description: A tale of two US gun ranges

item.title: The curious tale of the economist and the Cezanne in the hedge
item.description: How a Cezanne painting ended up in an English hedge

item.title: Getting rid of dirt - and murder victims
item.description: An element that helps get rid of dirt - and murder victims

item.title: Why South African whites are coming home
item.description: Why white South Africans are returning

item.title: India election: Taking the voters' pulse at tea shops
item.description: Mark Tully tries to gauge the mood of Indian voters

item.title: European elections: Too poor for a dress in Spain
item.description: Hard times for many of the women of Seville

item.title: VIDEO: 3D-printed house built in Amsterdam
item.description: The Dutch architects making an entire house using 3D-printing

item.title: Longest-separated twins find each other
item.description: Twins meet for the first time in 78 years - a new world record

item.title: The low-budget biopic riling Iran's president
item.description: Why a low-budget biopic is riling Iran's president

item.title: Swiss migration quotas: Rift with EU grows
item.description: Will migration row cut Swiss off from Europe?

item.title: How does Europe wean itself off Russian gas?
item.description: Europe looks to wean itself off Russian gas
